title: 5 things to know and the 14 methods to Amazon's madness
text:
5 things to know and the 14 methods to Amazon's madness Aug 17, 2015, 8:26am EDT Industries & Tags Dell Poncet Managing Editor Philadelphia Business Journal Dell Poncet Managing Editor Philadelphia Business Journal Home of the Day Enlarge 5 things to know today. It's Monday morning with a full week of work fun ahead of us all. What's the good word today? More on getting around Popedelphia Apparently, when the pope visits a city little stays the same way it was until he leaves. The latest changes to cope with the massive influx of people expected during Pope Francis' visit here are being reported by New Jersey Transit. “This will not be your average travel week,” said Ronnie Hakim , executive director of N.J. Transit and a master of understatement. “I cannot stress enough that the system will be pushed to capacity. We have a finite cadre of assets at our disposal as well as a constrained system.” Check out what Hakim is talking about in Patricia Madej's story . Who knew a transportation system that runs buses and trains has a cadre of anything? Sounds so Europeanish, doesn't it? Wharton is No. 3 You might have missed Dan Norton's article on the top 25 business schools for MBAs. The Wharton School is ranked No. 3 nation. One of its most prominent graduates is that demure and self-effacing fellow seeking the Republican nomination for president, Donald Trump . Where did your school rank? Learning how to learn Remember when going to school meant a book bag and books, both the text and note variety, and a teacher who stood in front of a blackboard? What a dinosaur you are. These days getting an education is so high-tech and complicated that I think the first thing that should happen is prospective students get an education in getting educated. You have to learn how to go to school. For example, witness Thomas Jefferson University's new learning management system called iCE. Again, it's Dan Norton with the details . Still not free from bias Women have been making inroads in the corporate world, but two recent studies show that there are still biases toward men, at least in certain sectors. A study by VitalSmarts found that women who assertive themselves at work are more likely than their male equals to take a hit in the pocketbook. While an experiment found that men are more successful when making venture capital pitches than women even if both use the same script. For more on this go to bizwomen . The Amazon way of the highway Everybody's been talking about the New York Times story about the brutal pressure-cooker atmosphere at Amazon . Some might say that is not for them, the rewards aren't worth it. Others, of course, their eyes light up to the challenge. Anyway, there are methods to Amazon's seeming madness. Here are its 14 "Leadership Principles."
